<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
February/March 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 227, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 115, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>+</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 354, 601, 370]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 370, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 400, 578, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 416, 277, 431]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 431, 868, 462]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 462, 330, 476]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 477, 364, 492]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 493, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 508, 670, 524]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 550, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 566, 570, 616]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

experimenttime for
20 oscillations/s
117.6

317.6
418.6

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 564, 89]]<|/det|> A metal wire is loaded up to the limit of proportionality. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 348, 119]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 133, 147]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 129, 784, 147]]<|/det|> Hooke's law is not obeyed when the load is increased from zero to this point. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 131, 175]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 156, 920, 189]]<|/det|> When the load is increased beyond the limit of proportionality, the diameter of the wire will increase. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 197, 133, 215]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 197, 680, 215]]<|/det|> When the load is removed, the wire returns to its original length. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 133, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 222, 774, 240]]<|/det|> Up to the limit of proportionality, there is no change in the shape of the wire. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 268, 96, 286]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 703, 286]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a uniform metre rule, MN, pivoted at its midpoint P. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 294, 720, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 401, 598, 419]]<|/det|> Two weights, \(W_{1}\) and \(W_{2}\), are hung either side of the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 432, 344, 448]]<|/det|> The rule remains balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 462, 297, 479]]<|/det|> Which row is correct? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 490, 630, 635]]<|/det|>
direction of resultant moment about point Mdirection of resultant force on the rule
Aclockwisedownwards
Bclockwisezero
Czerodownwards
Dzerozero

The cannonball is then fired from the cannon. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 298, 761, 316]]<|/det|> At time \(= t\), the cannonball moves forwards and the cannon moves backwards. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 329, 920, 361]]<|/det|> What happens to the total kinetic energy and the total momentum of the cannon and the cannonball between time \(= 0\) and time \(= t\)? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 373, 599, 517]]<|/det|>
total kinetic energy of cannon and cannonballtotal momentum of cannon and cannonball

The electrical output is \(10.6\mathrm{kW}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 591, 428, 608]]<|/det|> What is the efficiency of the scheme? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 618, 134, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 618, 210, 636]]<|/det|> 0.60% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 618, 303, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 618, 361, 636]]<|/det|> 17% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 618, 470, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 618, 527, 636]]<|/det|> 60% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[613, 618, 635, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 618, 693, 636]]<|/det|> 75% <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 662, 106, 681]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 662, 470, 681]]<|/det|> An object is at rest on a horizontal surface. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 694, 707, 712]]<|/det|> Which equation is used to calculate the pressure that the object exerts? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 725, 134, 744]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 720, 311, 738]]<|/det|> mass of the object <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 738, 301, 755]]<|/det|> area of contact <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 768, 134, 787]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 763, 324, 782]]<|/det|> weight of the object <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 781, 303, 798]]<|/det|> area of contact <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 808, 134, 825]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 807, 450, 824]]<|/det|> mass of the object \(\times\) area of contact <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 834, 134, 852]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 834, 460, 851]]<|/det|> weight of the object \(\times\) area of contact

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
Smoke particles, illuminated by a bright lamp, are seen through a microscope. They move about randomly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 117, 332, 135]]<|/det|>
What causes this motion?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 134, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 144, 705, 163]]<|/det|>
attraction between the smoke particles and the molecules of the air

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 171, 134, 190]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 170, 705, 189]]<|/det|>
collisions between the smoke particles and the molecules of the air

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 198, 131, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 197, 556, 216]]<|/det|>
evaporation of the faster-moving smoke particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 223, 133, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 222, 512, 241]]<|/det|>
warming of the smoke particles by the lamp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 268, 106, 286]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 267, 609, 286]]<|/det|>
Ether is a liquid that evaporates easily at room temperature.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 297, 767, 316]]<|/det|>
The rate at which ether evaporates can be increased by bubbling air through it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 390, 346]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows this process.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[353, 355, 641, 522]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 534, 920, 568]]<|/det|>
Students give three suggestions why the rate of evaporation increases when air is bubbled through.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 580, 735, 598]]<|/det|>
Student 1 suggests that the temperature of the ether is decreased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 606, 735, 625]]<|/det|>
Student 2 suggests that the surface area of the ether is increased.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 632, 824, 650]]<|/det|>
Student 3 suggests that evaporated molecules are removed at a greater rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 351, 680]]<|/det|>
Which students are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 689, 134, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 689, 218, 707]]<|/det|>
1 and 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 689, 298, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 689, 384, 707]]<|/det|>
1 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 689, 467, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 689, 552, 707]]<|/det|>
2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 689, 635, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 689, 707, 707]]<|/det|>
3 only

A graph is plotted of temperature against time. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[201, 112, 794, 272]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 284, 897, 303]]<|/det|> Which row describes what happens to the thermal energy and to the temperature in section X? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 312, 532, 444]]<|/det|>
thermal energytemperature of ice
Agained by icerises

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 715, 89]]<|/det|> Both boiling and evaporation involve a change of state from liquid to gas. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 101, 717, 120]]<|/det|> Which row gives the correct difference between boiling and evaporation? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 803, 259]]<|/det|>
boilingevaporation
Ano bubbles are formedbubbles are formed
Boccurs at all temperaturesoccurs at a definite temperature
Coccurs throughout the liquidoccurs at the surface only
Dthe temperature fallsthe temperature remains constant

Ripples are produced on the surface of the water. Refraction is observed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 469, 406, 487]]<|/det|> What causes the ripples to refract? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 497, 133, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 497, 591, 515]]<|/det|> The cold water in the tank is replaced by warm water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 524, 133, 542]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 524, 715, 542]]<|/det|> The ripples change speed as they move from deep to shallow water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 551, 133, 568]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 551, 435, 568]]<|/det|> The ripples hit the wall of the tank. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 577, 133, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 577, 477, 594]]<|/det|> The ripples pass through a narrow gap. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 619, 107, 637]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 618, 798, 637]]<|/det|> The diagram shows wavefronts of a water wave passing through a gap in a barrier. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 645, 618, 790]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 803, 808, 821]]<|/det|> Which change will increase the diffraction of the wave as it passes through the gap? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 832, 134, 850]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 832, 447, 850]]<|/det|> Increase the amplitude of the wave. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 860, 133, 878]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 860, 395, 878]]<|/det|> Increase the width of the gap. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 887, 133, 904]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 887, 376, 904]]<|/det|> Reduce the depth of water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 912, 133, 930]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 912, 440, 930]]<|/det|> Reduce the frequency of the wave.

It is perpendicular to both the magnetic field and the direction of the current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 106, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 73, 920, 121]]<|/det|> When a beam of \(\alpha \)-particles is incident on a thin metal foil, most of them follow a path represented by path X in the diagram. most follow path Xsome follow path Y
